ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: After taking similar classes in the past, this class was really helpful in further developing my ability to write prompts on command. In particular, I think this class helped me learn to write with restraint -- making conscious compositional decisions as opposed to using every trick in the book in every song. You always learn a lot from looking at other people's songs each week, and the course felt like a good way to apply what I've been learning in other theory and composition classes directly to my work.

This course is set up like a masterclass. Bring in music based on a prompt/assignment from the Professor and present in front of everyone to receive feedback. So, each week you may learn something new and also discover trends in your own musical writing that may need work.
I gained skills composing musical theater songs, as well as some good lyric-writing and text-setting experience.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Numbers were low this semester, and this class seems to work better with a few more people in it!
Strengths: weekly feedback from Professor Frankel and other students in the class, fun/exciting/creative prompts, predictable workload. No weaknesses as far as I can see, even over Zoom!

I appreciated the immersive nature of the course. Mainly, realizing I could compose and write something weekly was very good for me, and presenting assignments, reflecting on them in class, and hearing others do the same also taught me a surprising amount about the process.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course worked just fine online. It is nicer to perform your songs in person though, so it was a shame to miss out on that.

The class worked surprisingly well over Zoom, even though it usually relies on live music performance! We switched over to recording our pieces instead of performing them live, and the class ran without a hitch.
Sharing our demos and scores over Zoom turned out to work just fine.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! A good space to increase your understanding of writing MT songs, both standalone and in the context of wider work.

Absolutely! If you are considering a career in musical theater composition, or even if you are just interested in writing, this is the class for you. You will really hone your craft during this course, and class meetings are thoroughly enjoyable -- the highlight of my week every Friday. Be prepared for a high workload, though. You're writing a song every week, and I usually spent 3-4 hours per day at the piano writing my songs for class. Maybe I'm just a slow composer, though... If you're willing to commit to the high workload, you will get so much out of the class, and I highly recommend it.

Yes. It's deceptively difficult. It is a lot of work. It is hard to be creative and organized at the end of the week -- two things that the course requires. But, if you want to be a musical theater composer and have done work to pursue this, this is a course you must take. I wouldn't recommend coming in cold because there isn't much discussion on the basics of musical theater writing. The course assumes a lot of background knowledge, which is great for some but challenging for others.
This class was a really fun introduction to musical theater for me, as someone who had some very useful prior composing/scoring/writing skills and intuitions but otherwise didn't really know much.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
